in this fascinating game we chose to play! Ron

> pronunciation is /m/, so Namban. It is very difficult to pronounce /n/
> after the initial /n/, but some sources use that as the spelling. It
> is similar to the nengo Tenbun. Some sources give Tembun. I always use
> Namban and Tenbun, but some other sources use the alternative spelling.
>
> The carving explanation sounds reasonable, but I think there is a fair
> degree of ambiguity over many of these terms. And, thanks for getting
> back on the kanji stuff.
>
> Gordon
>

>> Interesting topic!
>>
>> See you in SF?
>>
>> Ron

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Name this dragon...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, It is, as Bob says, a pronunciation/spelling thing. The actual pronunciation is /m/, so Namban. It is very difficult to pronounce /n/ after the initial
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,

It is, as Bob says, a pronunciation/spelling thing. The actual
pronunciation is /m/, so Namban. It is very difficult to pronounce /n/
after the initial /n/, but some sources use that as the spelling. It
is similar to the nengo Tenbun. Some sources give Tembun. I always use
Namban and Tenbun, but some other sources use the alternative spelling.

The carving explanation sounds reasonable, but I think there is a fair
degree of ambiguity over many of these terms. And, thanks for getting
back on the kanji stuff.

Gordon

On Jul 31, 2010, at 7:30 AM, Ron Hartmann wrote:

> language thing!!!
>
> Same thing about the two carving techniques. As I thought, the one is
> carving away the ground to create low relief, the other carving out
> the
> design in what I've always heard was sunken relief...if that makes
> sense.
>
> Since you are involved with the NTHK, let me ask this. The name Namban
> (Nanban, in modern terms, so I hear) is a general term. There are the
> sub-catagories for those fittings. However, I've noticed that the
> NBTHK,
> auction houses, dealers, etc. (I don't have any NTHK examples) do
> not get so
> specific and call these things, "Namban." (Except perhaps for the most
> earliest examples?) Care to comment on this thinking for all to see???
> Interesting topic!
>
> See you in SF?
>
> Ron

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Name this dragon...
messages.msgSnippet: As far as I can tell, Nam and Nan are two pronunciations of the same character, both meaning southern, with ban meaning barbarian.   Not sure if this is what
messages.messageBody:
As far as I can tell, Nam and Nan are two pronunciations of the same
character, both meaning southern, with ban meaning barbarian. Not
sure if this is what you're looking for. B
On Jul 30, 2010, at 12:55 PM, Ron Hartmann wrote:

> More questions today...
>
> First question. I've never picked up on this before, but realized
> that both NAMBAN and NANBAN is used with describing these tsuba. Is
> there a simple explanation for this?
>
> Second question. What is the difference between the carving
> techniques, SUKIDASHI-BORI and SUKISAGE-BORI? My translated texts
> use the term sukisage-bori but glossaries seem to only define
> sukidashi-bori. I'm suspecting they describe the same technique of
> producing low relief by carving away the tsuba's surface metal.
>
> Just more confusion discovered when writing was was to be a simple,
> straight-forward namban tsuba article. (sigh)
>
> P.S. I'd like to ask Jim Gilbert a question. Jim, are you out there???
>
> Ron
> STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: JAYDC1388@...
> To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
> Sent: Tuesday, July 27, 2010 9:24 PM
> Subject: Re: Name this dragon...
>
> Hi Ron,
> Really neat tsuba, I believe these are water dragons the way they
> are done in Hizen style, I found a couple links below:
>
> this one has the closest silhouette but yours has more detail
>
> http://www.nihonto.com.au/html/tsu039_hizen_dragon_0.html
>
> click on zoom I think you can make out the beard
> http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/1021-jp-samurai-sword-water-
> dragon-menuki
>
> Pretty positive this is the right type of dragon. I'm sure your
> library is way superior to mine, and this will help point in the
> the right direction.
>
> Regards,
> Lance
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Name this dragon...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Gordon - Yes, several explanations came in that cleared this up for me, so don t worry about trying to explain it again. Takes some explaining but also
messages.messageBody:
Hi Gordon -

Yes, several explanations came in that cleared this up for me, so don't
worry about trying to explain it again. Takes some explaining but also takes
time to write it out! I admire you guys who have mastered all of this
language thing!!!

Same thing about the two carving techniques. As I thought, the one is
carving away the ground to create low relief, the other carving out the
design in what I've always heard was sunken relief...if that makes sense.

Since you are involved with the NTHK, let me ask this. The name Namban
(Nanban, in modern terms, so I hear) is a general term. There are the
sub-catagories for those fittings. However, I've noticed that the NBTHK,
auction houses, dealers, etc. (I don't have any NTHK examples) do not get so
specific and call these things, "Namban." (Except perhaps for the most
earliest examples?) Care to comment on this thinking for all to see???
Interesting topic!

See you in SF?

Ron
----- Original Message -----
From: "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, July 30, 2010 5:17 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Name this dragon...


> Hi Ron,
>
> I'm not answering this until I get a response on my last answer. Did
> that help? Did you figure anything out?
>
> Gordon
>
> On Jul 31, 2010, at 2:55 AM, Ron Hartmann wrote:
>
>> More questions today...
>>
>> First question. I've never picked up on this before, but realized
>> that both NAMBAN and NANBAN is used with describing these tsuba. Is
>> there a simple explanation for this?
>>
>> Second question. What is the difference between the carving

>> use the term sukisage-bori but glossaries seem to only define
>> sukidashi-bori. I'm suspecting they describe the same technique of

>> Just more confusion discovered when writing was was to be a simple,

>> P.S. I'd like to ask Jim Gilbert a question. Jim, are you out there???
>>
>> Ron
>> STL

messages.subject: Re: Name this dragon...
messages.msgSnippet: More questions today... First question. I ve never picked up on this before, but realized that both NAMBAN and NANBAN is used with describing these tsuba. Is
messages.messageBody:
More questions today...

First question. I've never picked up on this before, but realized that both NAMBAN and NANBAN is used with describing these tsuba. Is there a simple explanation for this?

Second question. What is the difference between the carving techniques, SUKIDASHI-BORI and SUKISAGE-BORI? My translated texts use the term sukisage-bori but glossaries seem to only define sukidashi-bori. I'm suspecting they describe the same technique of producing low relief by carving away the tsuba's surface metal.

Just more confusion discovered when writing was was to be a simple, straight-forward namban tsuba article. (sigh)

P.S. I'd like to ask Jim Gilbert a question. Jim, are you out there???

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: JAYDC1388@...
To: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Tuesday, July 27, 2010 9:24 PM
Subject: Re: Name this dragon...


Hi Ron,
Really neat tsuba, I believe these are water dragons the way they are done in Hizen style, I found a couple links below:


this one has the closest silhouette but yours has more detail

http://www.nihonto.com.au/html/tsu039_hizen_dragon_0.html


click on zoom I think you can make out the beard
http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/1021-jp-samurai-sword-water-dragon-menuki



Pretty positive this is the right type of dragon. I'm sure your library is way superior to mine, and this will help point in the the right direction.

Regards,
Lance
